Dear Mr. Soliz,
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Repeat violation require an explanation why the previous corrective action
plan was not successful.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 Indicate how continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 Be signed and dated.
A six-month provisional license is recommended. If you do not contest the issuance of a
provisional license, you must indicate so in writing; this may be included in your corrective
action plan or in a separate document. If you contest the issuance of a provisional license,
you must notify this office in writing and an administrative hearing will be scheduled. Even
if you contest the issuance of a provisional license, you must still submit an acceptable
corrective action plan.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days.

ALLEGATION:
A resident was able to get a hold of a razor and cut herself.
INVESTIGATION:
Resident A was interviewed at the facility on July 1 and July 9, 2020. Resident A
stated she had a "really bad meeting" with her Foster Care Worker from about 1pm-
2:30pm. At approximately 2:45pm, Resident A asked Staff 1 if she could
shower. According to Resident A, she and another resident share one
bathroom. Both residents keep basic items like shampoo and soap in the bathroom,
but their razors are kept locked in the staff bathroom. Resident A reported that when
she went into the shower, she noticed a razor in the bathroom. Resident A
proceeded to self-harm with the razor. Staff 1 became aware of the self-harming
when Resident A exited the bathroom and said that she needed stitches. Resident
A stated she was still on 5-minute checks due to previous suicidal thoughts, but staff
are not allowed to go into the bathroom with them and do not complete 5-minute
checks when residents are in the shower. Resident A denied any staff checked on
her while she was in the bathroom.
2

Resident A, Resident B and Resident C were interviewed on July 9, 2020. They all
reported the following:
 Residents hygiene items are stored in their bedroom or bathroom with
exception to razors.
 Razors are locked in the staff bathroom in a bin labeled with each resident’s
name
 Residents have to request the razor and return the razor when done.
Staff 1 was interviewed at the facility on July 1, 2020. Staff 1 stated Resident A was
upset following a meeting with her Foster Care Worker. Resident A left the house
but then returned while Staff 1 was following her. Staff 1 attempted to redirect and
distract Resident A offering to go for a walk with her, change the fishbowl, organize
the bookshelf, but Resident A continued to be agitated. Resident A asked to take a
shower. Staff 1 stated another resident was in the bathroom, so she did not let
Resident A into the bathroom. While in the milieu, Staff 1 walked to Resident A’s
bedroom and noticed she was not there. She talked to Resident A through the
bathroom door and Resident A stated she was okay. Within five minutes, Resident
A called for Staff 1. When Staff 1 walked to the bathroom she observed water and
blood as Resident A had cut her arms. She later located a disposable razor in the
bathroom that was used. Staff 1 denied providing Resident A with a razor. Staff 1
asked for staff assistance, and Resident A was provided with medical care and
taken to the hospital for further evaluation. Staff 1 stated Resident A was already on
At Risk Status due to suicidal ideation. She indicated eyes on checks are not
performed when residents are in the bathroom.
Staff 2 was interviewed at the facility on July 1, 2020. Staff 2 stated she attended a
Family Team Meeting with Resident A. Resident A was not happy with the outcome
of the meeting and became upset. Resident A threaten to AWOL and be defiant.
Resident A then asked for her sketching items including an eraser and pencil
sharpener. Staff 2 denied providing these items to Resident A as Resident A has
used these items to self-harm previously. Resident A asked Staff 1 to take a shower
and was given permission. Staff 2 did not see when Resident A entered the
bathroom so was not sure who opened the door or what items Resident A had with
her. Staff 2 stated Staff 1 requested assistance at some point as Resident A had
used a razor to cut her arms. Staff 2 stated Resident A was on At-Risk Status and
Staff 1 was assigned to supervise her. Staff 2 described At-Risk Status to mean
residents are checked on when sleeping in varying intervals not to exceed 15
minutes. If awake, staff document what the resident is doing in varying intervals not
to exceed 30 minutes. Staff 2 reported razors are locked in the staff bathroom and
need to be signed out for use.
I reviewed the video footage of the incident. Resident A was observed at 2:25pm
standing outside the closed bathroom door then walking to the milieu area. Another
resident exited the bathroom at 2:26pm and was walking down the hallway toward
the milieu area when Resident A walked back down the hallway to the bathroom
3

and entered. Staff 1 was observed to walk to the bathroom door at 2:34pm; knocks
on the door and is heard asking Resident A “how are you doing, are you taking a
shower”. Staff 1 returns to the milieu. Staff 1 walked to the bathroom door again at
2:41pm, then is seen opening the bathroom door and requesting further staff
assistance.
I reviewed the At-Risk Status Procedure that states if the Therapist or Program
Manager determine the need for searches of resident, resident room and bathroom
can be completed. The At-Risk Status Procedure later states unless clinically
inadvisable, resident room and bathroom searches should be completed at least
once daily while resident is on At-Risk Status.
I reviewed Resident A’s status records since she was admitted to the facility on
June 9, 2020.
 Resident A was placed on At-Risk Status on June 20, 2020 for AWOLing from
campus. The status was terminated on June 21, 2020.
 Resident A was placed on At-Risk Status on June 24, 2020 for self-harm as
she reported she ingested 19 pills to kill herself. The At-Risk Status Checklist
stated an initial bedroom search was completed but no further searches are
required. Specific instructions included eliminating Resident A’s access to
cords or sharp objects and to complete ten minute or less checks while
Resident A was awake.
o In review of the At-Risk Status Observation Log staff documented
checks exceeding 10 minutes from June 24-June 30, 2020 except for
two periods of time. On June 28 from 11:28am to 10:10 pm and June
30 from 5:35pm-6:55pm staff logged Resident A’s behavior at every
ten-minute increment.
 Resident A continued placement on At-Risk Status on June 30, 2020 for self-
harm as she used a razor to cut her arm. The At-Risk Status Checklist stated
an initial bedroom search was completed and daily searches should occur.
Specific instructions included eliminating Resident A’s access to sharp
objects and to complete five-minute checks per Resident A’s request. Also
noted Resident A was allowed use of headphones in her bedroom unless
staff have concerns. The status was terminated on July 8, 2020.
I reviewed Resident A’s safety plans since she was admitted to the facility.
 Safety Plan dated June 23, 2020: Peer Restriction/AWOLP Safety Planning
does not include any actions related to Resident A’s self-harm behavior.
 Safety Plan dated July 10, 2020: Plan includes staff monitoring for warning
signs and contacting Therapist if Resident A talks about her desire to self-
harm or self-harms. Room search will be completed if Resident A self-harms.
I reviewed the Razor sign in/out sheet, one resident checked out a razor on June 14,
2020 and it was not checked back in. During an onsite inspection on July 9, 2020, I
confirmed all St. John’s Home provided razors were accounted for in Haarmon
House by reviewing their storage in the locked staff bathroom.
4

I reviewed Student Privacy Policy and Search Procedure which states searches of a
residents self, bedroom or bathroom can be conducted when a Therapist indicates the
necessity of a search on a one-time, regular or random basis in order to ensure the
student’s safety and security.
During an onsite inspection on July 9, 2020, the bathroom was observed. A hair
straightener was in the bathroom. A room search was completed following this and
the facility found a hair dryer, curling iron, straightener, manicure set including two
nail clippers, bottles of shampoo, conditioner, body wash, bottle of nair and a metal
bottle cap.
Therapist 1 was interviewed via telephone on July 16, 2020. She reported she was
on call and placed Resident A on At-Risk status, but as she is not the assigned
therapist for Resident A she did not remove her from status. Therapist 1 stated the
facility’s status and procedures are not effective in ensuring safety of residents as
increased supervision is not specifically required. She noted if a resident is not on
status and has a history of self-harming behavior there is no policy allowing for
random or periodic searches. Searches’ are only completed when staff have a
concern a resident has contraband or if they are on a status requiring searches.
Therapist 2 was interviewed via telephone on July 15, 2020. She reported she is the
assigned therapist for Resident A. A safety plan was developed within the first few
weeks of Resident A being admitted to the facility as she went AWOL. There was
also a recent safety plan due to allegations of inappropriate contact between
Resident A and another resident while off campus. Therapist 2 was unaware of a
safety plan that was dated July 10, 2020. Therapist 2 reported residents belongings,
person, bedroom or bathroom are searched when returning from AWOL or when
they are placed on a status that indicates room searches should be completed. She
reported Resident A’s status was terminated, so there are currently no requirements
of room searches for Resident A. Therapist 2 was concerned with the items found in
Resident A’s bedroom on July 9, 2020 indicating those items should not have been
in any resident’s bedroom as hygiene items are to be stored in the locked staff
bathroom. Therapist 2 stated the status procedures are not effective as they are
reactive to a situation and lack proactive/prevention methods prior to the first
occurrence.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency's program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents.
5

ANALYSIS: The facility is found in non-compliance as facility did not provide
proactive measures or adequate supervision of Resident A to
ensure her continued safety and supervision to meet her needs.
Staff 2 failed to notify other staff of Resident A’s request for objects
used to self-harm. Although Staff 1 did check on Resident A while in
the bathroom twice, there was no proactive processes in place to
eliminate safety hazards for Resident A. Staff did not document
Resident A’s behavior every ten minutes as indicated on her At-Risk
Status Checklist.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED

ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
INVESTIGATION:
The following procedures were reviewed.
 Student Supervision Procedure: The purpose is to keep residents safe and
secure. Youth Development Specialist are responsible for direct supervision
of residents including knowing which residents are being supervised by which
staff at all times, knowing where each resident is at all times, being physically
present in close proximity to the resident, maintaining visual contact and
monitoring of the resident, monitoring interactions between residents,
accompanying and supervising residents whenever they move around
campus, and clearly communicating when the supervision of residents
transfers to another staff person. When residents are out of the direct
supervision of staff, staff shall perform variable interval, eyes-on checks of
residents not to exceed 15-minutes.
 Observation Status Procedure: The purpose is to temporarily provide
enhanced supervision and monitoring of a resident when standard
supervision guidelines may not be adequate to ensure student safety and
security. If it is suspected that a student needs supervision greater than
provided for in the Student Supervision Procedure, staff shall contact the
therapist while providing increased supervision to the student.
 At-Risk Status Procedure: The purpose is to temporarily provide extra
supervision to a student through increased monitoring. Staff members will
observe the student closely. Talk with him/her, and record observations and
interactions on the At-Risk Observation Log at varying intervals determined
by the Therapist, which must be at least every 30 minutes during waking
hours and 15 minutes during sleeping hours.
 Suicide Risk Status procedure: The purpose of Suicide Risk Status is to
detect the possibility of suicide and to prevent suicidal activity. Staff should
immediately assume a strict one-to-one suicide prevention watch where the
observing staff maintains constant “eyes on” supervision of the student.
6

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4109 Program statement.
(1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care, safety,
and supervision, methods for addressing residents' needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
ANALYSIS: The facility is found in non-compliance as the Status procedures do
not provide clear staff supervision expectations to ensure safety of
residents.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED

R 400.4151 Emergency; continuity of operation procedures.
(1) An institution shall establish and follow written emergency
procedures
that have been approved by the department that maintain the
continuity of operations for a minimum of 72 hours to assure the
safety of residents for the following circumstances:
(a) Fire.
(b) Severe weather.
(c) Medical emergencies.
(d) Missing persons.
(f) Disasters.
(g) Utility failures.
ANALYSIS: The facility is found in non-compliance as Therapist 1 was
observed not wearing the required Personal Protection
Equipment.
